h2_headers: ['Dont waste your time on Proof of Concept  it only ends up in a drawer somewhere anyway.', '1. Its not about technology its about the business value you want to achieve', '2. Get out of Proof of Concept hell!', '3. Your most important asset is STILL your employees', '4. Making the decision to invest in AI is great! But remember that THATs when the hard work begins…', '5. The speed of change is increasing exponentially']
paragraphs: ['Ive been around in the consulting industry since 2014. Before that I was a very critical buyer of consulting services which I believe has made me a better advisor and sparring partner for my current customers. In these glorious and adventurous days of artificial intelligence this critical sense has proved particularly important. The market is so full of magic dust and unrealistic promises about what artificial intelligence may bring in terms of prosperity success and eternal customer satisfaction. Working in this landscape every day with some of the most brilliant data scientists I have ever met Im also convinced that the world as we know it is changing and artificial intelligence plays an essential role. When I listen to lectures read articles and books or just reflect on the teams work I make notes in my very analogue black Moleskine which is always tagging along in my mobile handbag office. Here are five of my most important notes:', 'Ive been in many a customer meeting where the customer wants to assess different technologies for AI. Seriously it doesnt matter. Artificial intelligence is about applying mathematics and statistics to data usually solved through the programming language Python. Its like spending hours on debating the brand of screwdrivers with your carpenter. Dont. They will choose whatever works best for their purpose given the context of the job at hand. What matters to them and even more to you is what you want your house to look like when the work is done. If you fail in expressing what you want to achieve you are very likely to be extremely unsatisfied and youll have to redo the work.', 'The terms Proof of Concept (PoC) and pilot are often used interchangeably. They do mean different things though and the outputs are potentially VERY different. A PoC is about testing a concept or a technology to verify whether it makes sense in a given context. Typically a PoC is executed on very limited prerequisites with limited data and low precision requirements and without interaction with the surrounding operational environment. Consequently the results of the proof of concept typically ends up in a drawer far away from the CFOs nose. A pilot on the other hand is a limited production scope which means you start small but still aim for a full production scope and you have to think through the operational implications from the very start. It also means that youll be encouraged to prioritize processes that are truly relevant for your core business.', 'Lets have an example: A utilities company wants to develop a machine learning model to predict downtime of windmills in order to schedule maintenance with a proactive and preventive approach. The technical manager is an experienced guy with a long track-record in maintaining heavy equipment. No matter how good the predictive maintenance model you develop is you still need to convince the technical maintenance manager that his experience and gut feeling is about to be replaced (or better complemented) by an algorithm. If he is not in on this from the beginning dont waste your money (or your time) because in his eyes the algorithm will fail no matter how useful it couldve been. Yes artificial intelligence is about algorithms but your business is ultimately about people (your employees) who again work with people (customers).', 'Ive seen this scare some leaders into decision paralysis. Dont worry just start small and always keep your eyes on your business targets. Artificial intelligence is not magic. Its hard work experience and science. All those data you have collected for years are lying around waiting to be utilized. Structured systematic work by resources that are specialists in understanding the science of data in combination with your best domain specialists. Together they will unveil new insight about your business processes. Potentially worth millions. Perhaps hundreds of millions. Ive seen it happen.', 'Do you still believe that you can spend six months on strategy revisions? And another six months concluding on the business case? Sorry those days are over and theyre not likely to come back any time soon. You still need your long-term foundation and on top of that you need to develop an agile top management approach continuously learning from customers sparring partners and expert resources in the market. The days when a company could build and nurture all required competence and capacity internally are officially over.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

title: AI: Hype or headache?
subtitle: None
author: Elin Hauge
h2_headers: ['Dont let the dystopian image of AI scare you away from understanding how it actually affects your business.']
paragraphs: ['According to the pundits artificial intelligence (AI) can lead to a utopian future or overtake and destroy society. While there are proven use cases of AI and increasing investments in pragmatic applications this is outweighed by the hype factor  all the while we continue signing up for many more conferences summits and webinars on the topic.', 'Today still only 4% of European companies are using AI for several processes in the same business and in advanced tasks according to a report commissioned by Microsoft and conducted by EY [1]. 61% have started planning or are in the pilot phase of their first initiative. In a study by Siemens [2] 68% of the business leaders asked expect digitalization in general to primarily increase the efficiency of work processes while only 32% believe that digitalization will bring new business opportunities or new business models. At the same time the death of traditional retailers has become an international plague. How come? Why are companies moving so slowly when it comes to embracing digitalization in general and AI in particular? What will it take to speed up this progress?', 'Ill throw three hypotheses on the table:', 'What can we do then to speed up the rate of digitalization and application of AI?', 'My take is as follows: If you want to be part of the future of business as a leader or board member there is no way around it you have to upgrade your digital competence. You cannot just assign everything digital to some chief digital officer and continue with your own business as usual. There are many ways of achieving that necessary level of competence such as reading books and articles listening to podcasts watching Youtube inviting digital experts for a coffee signing up for a course etc. Whatever. Just do it. After all the key to succeeding with AI is NOT about technology its about our understanding of the technology.', '[1] Artificial Intelligence in Europe. author: Jesse Lord
h2_headers: ['The oil and gas industrys new toolset is transforming document swamps and making data more accessible.', 'Text is a four-letter word']
paragraphs: ['Our success at Amazon is a function of how many experiments we do per year per month per week per day.  Jeff Bezos', 'Since the advent of the internet many of our digitalisation projects have achieved little more than transforming a physical collection of books on a shelf to a collection of documents in a directory. Even today much of the information used to make key decisions in any industry resides in reports articles books and electronic communiqué. Natural Language Processing is a collection of techniques used to extract actionable information from these unstructured collections. It is being used today for a variety of tasks from finance (to extract signals from news articles as input to trading algorithms) to search engine queries and machine translation.', 'A tremendous amount of resources are devoted to machine learning activities within the Exploration & Production departments of the worlds Oil & Gas companies. Progress is being made on automating key workflows and some scientific literature can even be processed efficiently enough to perform sentiment analysis. But while we spend a great deal of time discussing our metrics and methodologies data scientists still spend an inordinate amount of time on preparing the data.', 'The Norwegian National Data Repository for exploration and production data (Diskos) contains over 26 000 publicly available reports. We can quickly scan and index the content of these documents to make them easy to search but programmatically extracting further meaning is not a trivial matter. When I consider the amount of time and money that has gone into the creation of each of these reports it seems a great pity that the only reliable way to derive full value from them is for a seasoned expert with a good memory to read them and disseminate the knowledge throughout their organisation.', 'To pick just one example of the kind of value that can be extracted from a text document; consider the references to good shows found in final well reports. Last year I was lucky enough to be part of a team at the Force Machine Learning Hackathon where we programmatically extracted these good shows with depth from Final Well Reports and plotted them on an interactive map. Check out the write-up here.', 'While there is no quick fix for extracting value from unstructured text files Id like to recommend a simple step towards the structured utopia so often featured on those glossy PowerPoint slides. Enter insight engines.', 'An insight engine is conceptually similar to a data lake: it automatically crawls through the various data sources in an enterprise (internal and external) and allows users to quickly answer a complex query typically via a web interface. If you want to find a set of documents containing a specific word or phrase for example both solutions allow you to rapidly locate them based on content or associated metadata. The difference lies in the connectors enrichment and natural language search capabilities.', 'Consider what is required for the insight engine to answer a question such as: Which log files do I have for wellbores that have a bottom depth in the Tarbert formation?', 'This query relies on data sources enriched metadata and natural language specific to the oil & gas industry and would only be relevant for companies operating in the Norwegian Continental Shelf. To honour this request the insight engine needs to understand all the different potential formats of log file (both the open standards and those that reside within E&P projects/databases) what a wellbore entity is what its bottom depth is and finally reconcile this bottom depth with the lithostratigraphic formation data (which could come from a variety of sources). Finally once the structured elements hidden within the question have been assembled relevant records from a variety of different sources are presented to the user. Because of this complexity many insight engine vendors focus on a single vertical. My company (KADME) is no exception and we focus exclusively on the E&P vertical with our insight engine Whereoil.', 'This kind of enrichment can be very useful as a basis for building machine learning models that take advantage of natural language processing. We can get a number of features for free without needing to engineer them manually. Further by building our query to pull data from an API we can integrate live data into the pipeline. This keeps our models alive and relevant and gives us the option of phasing out older data that may no longer be helpful. If you have access to a platform like this in your organisation consider integrating its API into your machine learning pipeline.', 'Data wrangling may not be particularly exciting but it is very time consuming. Using an insight engine that understands your industry and comes with a robust open API can really streamline the process. This means more time to iterate optimise and ultimately get more experiments done using the same project resources.']

title: Gjør roboter smartere med enkle grep
subtitle: None
author: Oda Aase Johnsen
h2_headers: ['En automatisert prosess kan spare deg både penger og tid men hvorfor ikke sikre deg den beste du kan?']
paragraphs: ['Antall ledere som mener de trenger et «RPA-prosjekt» for å få automatisert prosessene sine øker stadig. Det mange ikke er klar over er at RPA (Robotic Process Automation) alene ofte ikke er den beste løsningen de kunne ha fått.', 'Når en bruker RPA for å automatisere prosesser slipper man å tenke på integrasjon mellom IT-systemene som berøres av en prosess fordi RPA forholder seg direkte til brukergrensesnittet. Kort forklart arbeider en RPA-robot som en vanlig ansatt med i all hovedsak de samme klikkene som en fysisk medarbeider og kan åpne og lukke programmer etter behov. Dette er en stor lettelse for ledere som i mange år har måttet skrinlegge IT-prosjekter grunnet tid og kostnader. Bruker en RPA kan en relativt kompleks prosess bli ferdig automatisert på få uker. At mange ledere derfor kontakter ulike leverandører av rene RPA-løsninger er dermed ganske lett å forstå.', 'Det mange ledere derimot ikke er klar over er at det er mulig å kombinere RPA med for eksempel API-spørringer (Application Programming Interface). API-er kan sammenlignes med en servitør på en restaurant. Du forteller servitøren hva du ønsker å spise servitøren formidler dette videre til kokken som lager maten og til slutt kommer servitøren tilbake med maten du har bestilt. Ved hjelp av API-spørringer kan du for eksempel «snakke med» CRM-systemet ditt uten å skulle arbeide direkte på brukergrensesnittet. Dette er ofte en langt mer robust løsning fordi en da ikke må «lære opp roboten» på nytt dersom det blir endringer på brukergrensesnittet. I eksempelet med servitøren betyr dette for eksempel at du ikke trenger å skulle tenke på om kjøkkenverktøyet plutselig ligger på en annen plass enn tidligere.', 'Videre kan en også kombinere RPA med blant annet språkmotorer som kan tolke ustrukturert tekst. Nyttiggjør en seg av dette kan roboten din dermed ikke bare arbeide basert på forhåndsdefinerte regler men den har faktisk blitt en god del smartere.', 'For å ende opp med den beste løsningen er det med andre ord viktig å endre tankegangen fra at virksomheten trenger et «RPA-prosjekt» til at virksomheten trenger å få automatisert en prosess på best mulig måte uavhengig av teknologi.']

author: Vidar Furuholt
h2_headers: ['Her er tre tips for å hente ut store digitaliseringsgevinster også i Norges mest høyteknologiske industri.']
paragraphs: ['Leting etter olje og gass er en industri som i mange tiår har skjøvet grenser for digital teknologi. Seismiske undersøkelser genererer enorme mengder data og til prosessering og analyse av disse benyttes noen av de største regneklyngene som til enhver tid er å oppdrive. Avansert modellering og simulering 3D-visualisering og automatisert geologisk tolkning har vært en del av letegeologenes- og geofysikernes verktøykasse i en årrekke. Oljedirektoratets database for seismikk og brønndata på norsk sokkel Diskos inneholder omlag 10 petabyte data og vokser raskt.', 'Hva betyr begrepet digitalisering for en bransje og et fagområde som har vært blant de ledende på bruk av digital teknologi siden hullkortenes tid?', 'Det første er erkjennelsen av at data kun kan oppnå full nytteverdi når de er enkelt tilgjengelige for bruk. En historikk for datainnsamling som strekker seg over et halvt århundre og en like lang arv av programvare for håndtering av disse har gitt et mylder av filformater databaser og lagringssystemer med dårlig innbyrdes kompatibilitet. Resultatet er at data vanskelig lar seg hente ut av ett system for å benyttes i et annet og data fra ulike fagdisipliner er tungvinte å sammenstille for analyse på tvers. I tillegg er dataene ofte dårlig strukturert og har mangelfull metainformasjon noe som gjør det vanskelig å se sammenheng mellom objekter og vurdere datakvalitet. Det jobbes derfor intensivt hos en rekke aktører i bransjen med å etablere dataplattformer som kan frigjøre data fra deres opprinnelige formater og lagringssystemer øke kontekstualiseringen og bedre tilgjengeligheten for applikasjoner. Sentrale elementer her er utvikling av robuste datamodeller og APIer for datautveksling samt standardisering av disse. Hvilken mekanisme som skal sørge for standardisering er ennå et åpent spørsmål  både konsortier kommersielle grupperinger og myndighetsinitiativ kan vise seg å definere retningen. Trolig er det den som greier å etablere nok moment til å få nettverkseffekten på sin side som stikker av med seieren. Det viktigste er uansett at bransjen evner å lande på teknisk gode standarder med størst mulig grad av åpenhet og fleksibilitet for tilpasning til spesifikke behov.', 'Videre er maskinlæring et sentralt begrep i digitalisering også for letebransjen. Maskinlæring generelt har lange tradisjoner innenfor geofagene  autotolkning av seismikk har eksempelvis eksistert i mange år  men store nevrale nettverk er relativt nytt. Prestasjonen til store nevrale nettverk bestemmes først og fremst av mengde og kvalitet av treningsdata. Det betyr at desto mer aktørene i bransjen åpner opp og deler sine data desto bedre kan verktøy basert på nevrale nettverk bli  for alle. Deling av data krever to elementer: tekniske løsninger som gode dataplattformer med åpne APIer og motivasjon til å dele hos de som eier data. På norsk sokkel har vi gode rammeverk for deling og offentliggjøring av data sammenlignet med mange andre land gjennom stabile myndighetsbestemmelser og tekniske løsninger som nevnte Diskos. Likevel er store mengder data proprietære og dermed utilgjengelige for allmenheten. Bransjen utfordres nå til å vurdere etablerte forretningsmodeller rundt eierskap til data i lys av det nye verdipotensialet som ligger i større grad av datadeling for maskinlæring.', 'Med god datatilgang i bunn er neste steg å finne fram til de verdifulle anvendelsene for maskinlæring og nevrale nettverk. Oljeindustrien støtter både offentlig og privat forskning og utvikling med betydelige midler innenfor dette området og interessen er raskt økende i takt med at spennende løsninger utvikles og kommer ut i markedet. Et hackathon sist høst sponset av en rekke oljeselskaper leverandører og Oljedirektoratet genererte prosjekter på blant annet mønstergjenkjenning på seismikk automatisk analyse av kjerneprøver fra brønner og et verktøy til å omsette håndskisser til syntetiske data. Men her har vi ennå bare skrapt i overflaten av mulighetsrommet. Bedre allmenn tilgang til relevante letedata vil kunne løfte økosystemet av utviklere og leverandører og betydelig øke tilfanget av gode ideer.', 'Begrepet digitalisering er i ferd med å konkretiseres for letebransjen og aktørene begynner å få øynene opp for mulighetene og verdipotensialet. Men for å lykkes er det ikke nok at aktørene investerer i egne prosjekter. Man må også evne å samarbeide både med partnere og konkurrenter være villig til å dele kunnskap og teknologi og til og med vurdere egen forretningsmodell og rolle i markedet. Det er utfordrende men gevinsten ved å lykkes er større enn ulempene.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

title: Let’s Look at Oslo City Bike Data

author: Dmitry Semashkov
h2_headers: ['With more than 50000 members and 2.7 million rides made in 2017 Oslo City Bike has long been an important part of the local transport system.']
paragraphs: ['The company that runs the service regularly releases historic trip data. That gives us an opportunity to explore and visualize bike rides and quite possibly get an insight into some patterns of usage.', 'The animation below displays all of the bicycle trips that occurred on a specific day 15 September 2017. Since the data only contains the station where each journey started and the station where it finished I created an estimated path which follows the cycling directions from Google Maps from start to finish.', 'It is possible to notice some regular patterns. First we can notice two busy periods  in the morning from 8:00 to 9:00 and in the evening from 15:00 to 19:00. The rest of the day is less busy.', 'We can find this trend in the data if we plot the number of bike rides by hour of the day. It makes sense to look at the data for weekdays separately since the behavior is quite different during weekends.', 'Another trend is a little bit more subtle and relates to the direction of travel. Lets have a look at the number of bike journeys started at specific stations throughout the day:', 'In the morning we can see how areas outside of city center light up. Then in the evening the same happens in the central areas. Clearly there are more bikes used outside of city center in the morning and in the center in the evening. But we have seen where the journey starts. Lets have a look where it ends.', 'But before we check the data lets have one more look at our original animation. We can paint the bikes going in and out of the city center with different colors:', 'We can clearly see more green dots during the morning peak (meaning more trips to the center) and more purple dots during the evening peak (out of center). Lets verify this by checking the data:', 'Again we found evidence. Interesting that a lot of people seem to travel both in and out of city during evening peak. I speculate that while some people use city bikes to commute to/from work other people are attracted to the city center and all the services it offers  be it restaurants shopping etc. but thats just a guess.', 'Lets have look at other usage statistics to get an idea about how the Oslo City Bike operates.', 'If we look at the number of trips made in 2017 we can clearly see seasonal variations:', 'At the same time there is not much variation in the number of trips taken on a day to day basis except for weekends when people seem to take the city bike less often…', '…but for longer periods:', 'Also I was quite surprised to find out that short trips are much more common than long trips. Trips lasting 4 10 minutes happen much more often than any other trips:', 'Probably unsurprising is the distribution between the most used and the least used stations  it seems that stations closer to center are used most. Usage during one day:', 'It seems that the pattern does not change much if we zoom out and collect statistics for the whole month:', 'This last map is the heatmap which approximates the roads most frequently used by cyclists in September 2017. As before the precise route is not known so every rider is assumed to use Google Maps to navigate from pickup station to the return station).', 'Yet again the statistics collected for the whole month only differ from the daily statistics in minor details which can be easily observed if you follow the links and compare the maps.', 'Its quite interesting to see how things are changing with time. If you look at the excellent analysis of 2016 bike data made by Jon Olav H. Eikenes you can see that while some patterns didnt change there is a tendency for shorter bike trips in 2017 compared to 2016.', 'There is always room for further analysis: correlation to weather and air quality traffic conditions predicting the journeys on station levels analyzing the need for new stations comparing bike systems to public transport data or taxi etc. etc. etc.  just a short list of topics this study could be extended to. Maybe next time!']

h2_headers: ['Også når det gjelder teknologi er det slik at om noe er for fantastisk til å være sant så er det gjerne det: ikke sant.', 'Påfuglens vifting', 'Turgåer i data-landskap', 'En del av hverdagen', 'Menneskelig kreativitet']
paragraphs: ['Robotene kommer! Arbeidsplassen din vil bli automatisert. Om et par år er det ingen som kjører selv lengre. Kampen om algoritmene vil føre til tredje verdenskrig. Datamaskiner vil oppdage sykdommer lenge før fastlegen din. Inn fra venstre kommer det språkteknologi som vil snu opp ned på språkforskningen. Menneskeheten er i ferd med å skape en intelligens større enn seg selv. Med de siste utviklingene innenfor kunstig intelligens står vi nå i et uavklart sted mellom utopi og dystopi. Vil utviklingen føre til vår undergang eller vår frelse?', 'Det er i hvert fall ikke rart at det snakkes mye om maskinlæring og kunstig intelligens i mediene for tiden. De som følger med i dingseverdenen har trolig også fått med seg et at teknologigigantene ikke nøler med å bruke dette i markedsføringen av sine produkter. Det å hevde at man mestrer og kan bruke maskinlæring er nå markedets svar på påfuglens vifting med en alt for stor halestjert. Til tross for at teknologien maskinvaren og datastrømmene aldri har vært mer tilgjengelige så er maskinlæring vanskelig i praksis. Hovedsakelig fordi man trenger menneskelig hjernekraft for å lære maskinene til å lære som mennesker. Men investorene flokker seg rundt allikevel  og man kan spørre seg om troen fremdeles er mer drivende i markedet enn fornuften.', 'Grunnen er nok at det er få som tar seg bryet med å forklare hva maskinlæring egentlig er for noe. Jeg prøvde meg på det tidligere i vår i to seminarer jeg holdt for studenter i Digital kultur ved Det humanistiske Fakultet på UiB. Ideene bak maskinlæring  som tross alt også er et bredt felt  er ganske overkommelige om man tar vekk den tekniske sjargongen.', 'Det ble også klart for oss hvor lett det er å ta maskinlæringens frukter for gitt og hvor viktig det er at vi også lærer oss å tenke kritisk på områder hvor det er lett å la seg rive med.', 'På post-it lappene vi brukte i undervisningen hadde studentene skrevet ord som «intuisjon» «objektivitet» «følelser» «etikk» «juss» og «singulariteten». Bak matematikken som kraftige maskiner bruker på masse data ligger det vanskelige spørsmål som har vært med menneskeheten fra vi selv fikk tankekraft nok til å tenke i bilder og symboler.', 'Men grunnprinsippene er likevel enkle: Målet er å finne en slags oppskrift som kan brukes for å kategorisere noe fra noe annet  helst uten at vi trenger å fortelle dataprogrammet så mye om hvordan den skal gjøre det selv. Det er en del forskjellige innfallsvinkler til hvordan vi gjør dette i praksis men de innebærer stort sett at datamaskiner regner seg frem til veldig mange sannsynligheter mellom veldig mange variabler på veldig mye data for å så trekke dette sammen i en modell som vi kan bruke videre.', 'Vi kan tenke oss dataprogrammet som en turgåer i et stort kupert data-landskap som forandrer seg litt hele tiden. Turgåeren går ned over dalen litt på måfå og prøver å ikke sette seg fast i busker eller søkk. Vi kan be vandreren å ta med seg noen erfaringer fra tidligere turer eller konkurrere med en annen turgåer. Vi kan også plassere noen varder i landskapet som hjelper turgåeren litt på vei.', 'Det som gjør maskinlæring rart er at vi sliter med å forklare hvordan turgåeren har tenkt på veien og hvorfor hen alltid kommer frem til den avtalte møteplassen. Vi vet at det antageligvis er noe mer enn flaks.', 'Hver uke blir det publisert nye akademiske artikler fra de som jobber med dette hos teknologigigantene hvor man har gjort nye oppdagelser men samtidig påpeker hvor dårlig det er forstått.', 'Denne uvissheten gir også feltet en mystisk aura. Løftet om kunstig intelligens  som i dag tillegges maskinlæring  ligger tett opp til ideer vi har utforsket i science fiction og populærkulturen siden før den kunstige intelligensen HAL9000 i Stanley Kubrick og Arthur C. Clarkes 2001 A Space Odyssey. Slik kunstig intelligens blir ofte fremstilt som allvitende gudelignende vesen med intensjoner og hensikter utenfor vår kontroll. Det er fristende å bruke det latinske religionsvitenskapelige uttrykket «mysterium tremendum et fascinans»; opplevelsen av noe vi ikke helt forstår og finner både attraktivt og skummelt.', 'Og samtidig er maskinlæring en del av hverdagen vår. Vi har allerede hatt maskinlærings-boter som har handlet på aksjemarkedet i over ti år og det er få som hever et øyebryn når bildesøket til Google fungerer som forventet. De skeptiske øyenbrynene bør senke seg når det hevdes at man besitter maskinlærings-teknologi som skal løse brede og generelle problemområder som for eksempel diagnostisering personalhåndtering eller husarbeid.', 'Også når det gjelder teknologi er det slik at om noe er for fantastisk til å være sant så er det gjerne det: ikke sant. Maskinlæring står kun for en liten del av det som får «smarte» løsninger til å fungere. Man må også inn med god gammaldags programmering design og kostnadseffektive prioriteringer. Det trengs med andre ord fremdeles en solid porsjon menneskelig kreativitet pågangsmot og utholdenhet for å skape morgendagens løsninger. Da holder det ikke kun med markedsføring.', 'Denne teksten er også publisert på Sysla.no']

title: Should you bother developing a recommendation engine?
subtitle: None
author: Didrik Finnoy
h2_headers: ['Its all about providing the users with buttons they want to push and theres plenty of room to be creative.', 'Heres a bunch of stuff wed like you to consume', 'Here are a bunch of suggestions you might actually find helpful', 'Size matters', 'An unusual example', 'So should you bother developing a recommendation engine?']
paragraphs: ['We need to talk about recommendation engines. Over the past decade theres been a tremendous push toward data-driven marketing and personalized customer experiences; a recent survey by Harris Poll indicates that most people expect consumer experiences to be tailored toward their individual tastes and preferences. At first glance a recommendation engine may seem like an elegant way for online retailers to fulfill this somewhat vague expectation. Before pursuing this type of technology one should think carefully about how it will benefit customers  it might not be the type of personalization theyre asking for.', 'The principal idea behind a recommender system is to present consumers with products and services they might be interested in with respect to what the system knows about them. Most of the time the business value of these systems is to boost sales. In that sense one could argue that personalized content is just a fancy word for effective advertising. Have you ever caught yourself thinking Gosh life sure would be sweeter if that screen space contained more relevant advertisements? I would wager that your answer is no. After decades of enduring that colorful noise often decorated with scantily clad supermodels weve grown accustomed to ignoring the automated salesman. In most cases nobody would notice the absence of an excellent recommendation engine.', 'Its important to remember that contexts differ and that personalized recommendations can be very useful. Imagine if YouTube suddenly abandoned their recommender systems in favor of simply listing content in alphabetical order. People would be outraged… or at least mildly inconvenienced. There are certain websites on the internet where recommendation engines play a crucial role in how consumers interact with content  YouTube and Netflix being prominent examples. For sites like Amazon this is arguably less true. Sure there are Amazon shoppers who enjoy browsing their personal recommendations but I think the average customer wouldnt care if Amazon replaced their recommender systems with completely random product suggestions. E-commerce websites differ in the extent that consumers actually benefit from recommendation engines. For most Amazon customers a product handpicked by the engine is just another advertisement while on YouTube the same type of system can be instrumental in deciding whether one ends up bored or entertained. The distinction between pushing content to boost revenue and actually helping customers can be difficult to pinpoint. Most of the time a recommender system ends up doing both.', 'When I read about developing recommendation engines (I work as a Data Science Consultant at Atea so Im sometimes asked to build such systems) I frequently come across the following piece of advice:', 'Dont build a recommendation engine unless your website gets a lot of traffic.', 'The rationale behind the advice is perfectly reasonable: If you dont get a lot of traffic from shoppers visiting your website your recommendation engine wont get many opportunities to create value. I dont necessarily think that this is good advice. Sure it makes sense if your goal is to turn a profit but thats not the only motivation one might have to develop a recommender system. For sites like Netflix recommendation engines are all about the user experience. The engines are valuable irrespective of how many people subscribe to their service. Traffic is still relevant because it determines how much time and resources it makes sense to invest in improving the system. Back when Netflix only had a few thousand customers a simple solution would probably be better than nothing but it wouldnt make sense to spend big money without expecting something in return. Today Netflixs recommender systems probably have a big impact on churn prevention and maintaining a competitive edge and Im sure the sizable investments theyve made toward developing their recommendation technology are paying off. From Amazons point of view their size is what makes recommender systems worth the effort even if the average shopper tends to completely ignore their recommendations. When you have hundreds of millions of customers the occasional extra sale generated through recommendations can amount to sizable figures.', 'Ive been assisting a local brewery Hansa Borg Bryggerier with developing a recommendation engine for their online sales portal. A prerequisite for accessing this portal is that you must hold a license to serve alcohol in Norway. This means that relatively few businesses are allowed to use the website and that its never going to see large amounts of traffic. If we were to follow the advice referenced above we wouldve abandoned the idea of developing a recommender system. We didnt abandon it because Hansa Borg saw great potential with respect to personalizing the customer experience.', 'The goal behind this particular system was to assist customers in the hospitality sector when they perform the regular task of ordering beverages and supplies. Using a recommender system to boost sales probably wouldnt work well in this context. Bars and restaurants are a lot less likely to make frivolous purchases compared to individuals shopping for miscellaneous products on Amazon. Taking on a new product usually entails extra work (updating menus training staff etc.) which isnt what bar and restaurant managers have on their mind when they contact Hansa Borg to restock their supplies.', 'Every recommendation engine needs some sort of key performance indicators. For Amazon this is probably clicks or purchases or both. For Hansa Borg the KPIs were how long it takes a customer to get the job done and how often they have to come back to order more stuff within the same week. Its not uncommon for their customers to place several orders within a single week usually because they forget some stuff the first time around. Our ambition was to minimize the time spent on the site and help customers find everything they need on the first attempt. These business goals presented us with the need for a somewhat unusual recommendation engine.', 'Under the hood the goal of most recommender systems is to find products similar to the stuff youve consumed in the past. The traditional recommender algorithms would not do the trick for us instead we defined our task as a time-series classification problem. This is a fairly established type of problem in the world of machine learning but I have not seen it employed within the context of product recommendations before which is why I have the audacity to claim that our recommendation engine is an unusual one.', 'Hansa Borg has a fairly good idea about what each customer is going to order in the future because their menus are quite stable over time. The main source of uncertainty is when they will need to resupply the various items on the menu. As it turns out this is a question that machine learning algorithms are well equipped to answer. After feeding historical sales data through several candidate classification algorithms we began seeing promising results fairly early in the process. The vision of a website where the first thing you see is exactly what you need was firmly within reach. As a matter of fact this feature is about to go live and Im fairly excited about it. The Hansa brand is part of the cultural identity of my home town; this is the beer my grandfather drank and Im known for consuming responsible quantities of it myself. It has been a real honor and a privilege to make my own small contribution toward their wider goal of becoming a more data-driven organization.', 'Whether or not recommender systems make sense for your website depends entirely on your context. If youre certain that it will benefit your customers I would say go for it  but be mindful of the costs. If its all about boosting sales and unlikely to actually benefit your customers then the size will be pivotal; dont bother unless youre seeing a lot of traffic. Like most things in business costs should be weighed against benefits. These days you can develop a recommender system in less than a day it doesnt have to be fancy and there are plenty of off-the-shelf solutions that will probably do the trick just fine.', 'In my opinion famous examples like Netflix and Amazon are dominating the literature on recommender systems. Most tutorials blog posts and how-to guides are geared toward tackling the problem in terms of collaborative- or content-based filtering forgetting that the concept of providing personalized recommendations is much broader. Dont abandon the idea of developing a recommender system simply because the Netflix / Amazon approach doesnt fit your context. When we break it down to the core concept its all about providing users with buttons that they want to push; there is plenty of room to be creative. Whatever your ambitions are with respect to technology make sure you think big start small and move fast.', 'Dette innlegget ble originalt publisert hos Atea og her kan du lese mer om deres arbeid med Hansa Borg Bryggeri.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

title: “Stakkars Norge…”
subtitle: None
author: Elise Fehn Unsvåg
h2_headers: ['Det trengs bedre grep om hva hat er og språkmodeller må forstå både innhold og kontekst for å kunne redusere netthat. Alt uten å utfordre ytringsfriheten.', 'Å identifisere hat er kjempevanskelig', 'Mer data og riktig data', 'Det er et definisjonsspørsmål']
paragraphs: ['Natural Language Processing (NLP) er et område innen maskinlæring som omhandler maskiners forståelse av menneskelig språk. Denne teknologien kjenner vi allerede godt fra chatbots spam-filtrering og stemmestyring. Potensielle bruksområder er enda fler og det er nå et økende antall studier som ser på bruken av maskinlæring og NLP for å oppdage netthat.', 'Hatefulle ytringer er et økende problem på nettet. Store og små nettsider og sosiale nettverk vil ha stor nytte av språkmodeller som automatisk gjenkjenner og fjerner uønsket og ulovlig netthat ettersom denne prosessen i stor grad består av manuelt arbeid i dag.', 'Men å implementere en sånn språkmodell er lettere sagt enn gjort. Jeg skal prøve å fortelle hvorfor.', 'Fra et NLP-perspektiv er det mange grunner til at hat er vanskelig å oppdage.', 'Per nå finnes det ikke et godt datasett for sammenligning av ulike modeller og metoder og det er mange årsaker til det.', 'I bunn og grunn handler dette problemet om at ulovlig hat mangler en entydig definisjon. Hvis en språkmodell skal lære å gjenkjenne hat må den lære hva hat er og hva hat ikke er.', 'Uten en definisjon vil forskere eller utviklere selv fortelle modellen hva hat er og dermed introdusere subjektivitet i modellen. Subjektivitet kan blant annet føre til at ikke alt hat blir oppdaget eller at noe blir feilaktig kategorisert som hat og kan dermed være med på å krenke ytringsfriheten.', 'Til tross for alle disse utfordringene kan språkmodeller i dag brukes som gode hjelpemidler for å kunne gjenkjenne trusler eller til å flagge potensielt hat raskt og effektivt. Dermed kan mennesker vurdere hva som skal fjernes som mye enklere kan vurdere kontekst og intensjon.', 'Hvor burde fokuset være videre? Først og fremst er det viktig å utforske konteksten av hatet og ikke bare utvikle modeller som bare tar hensyn til teksten i seg selv. Eksempler på kontekst kan være bilder innhold i lenker eller informasjon om de som skriver hatefullt innhold.', 'Videre er det viktig å lage gode datasett. Dette er viktig for sammenligning av forskningresultater og for et bedre samarbeid mellom de som jobber med å utvikle språkmodeller slik at vi forhåpentligvis en gang kan se en ende på ulovlig netthat.']

title: Teknikkar for Auka Røynd (AR)
subtitle: None
author: Jon Olav H. Eikenes
h2_headers: ['Nokon kallar det auka røynd andre kallar det augmented reality (AR). Uansett kva du kallar det  AR har dei siste åra gått frå å vere ein våt framtidsdraum til å verte noko som faktisk fungerer.', 'Optisk blanding på ekstern flate', 'Digital blanding på ekstern flate', 'Optisk blanding i skjermbriller', 'Digital blanding i skjermbriller', 'Gir modellen meining?']
paragraphs: ['Dette innlegget er eit forsøk på å kategorisere AR-landskapet med fokus på ulike teknikkar ein kan nytte for å utvide røynda.', 'AR-teknikkar gjer at folk kan sjå virtuelle gjenstandar og grafikk lagt oppå den fysiske røynda. Azuma (1997) definerte AR som system som er interaktive i realtid og kombinerer verkelege og virtuelle gjenstandar i 3D. Denne definisjonen er vid og inkluderer dermed ei rekke teknikkar.', 'I EU-prosjektet SEDNA forskar vi på korleis AR kan nyttast på skip som skal navigere i Arktis. For å gjere dette treng vi ein praktisk og forståeleg oversikt over ulike AR-teknikkar.', 'Dette er ikkje første gongen nokon prøver å kategorisere AR. For eksempel beskreiv Milgram m.fl. (1994) auka røynd som eit kontinuum mellom verkelege og virtuelle omgjevnader. Eg trur det er nyttig å skisse ut meir konkret kva teknikkar som er tilgjengelege når ein skal designe for AR.', 'Det er to viktige dimensjonar ved AR-teknologi: kvar brukaren ser den utvida røynda og korleis teknologien blandar røynda og den virtuelle grafikken.', 'Eg foreslår å skilje mellom eksterne flater og skjermbriller for å beskrive kvar utvidinga skjer (horisontal akse i diagrammet under) og optisk og digital blanding (vertikal akse) for å indikere korleis den fysiske og virtuelle verda vert kombinert.', 'I eit 2x2 diagram ser dette slik ut:', 'I hjørnet øvst til venstre finn vi eksterne flater som nyttar optisk blanding. Brukarene ser verda som vanleg i tillegg til eit ekstra visuelt lag.', 'Denne teknikken inkluderer ulike typar head-up display (HUD). Nokre bilar nyttar denne teknikken for å vise fart og navigasjonsinformasjon på frontruta og teknikken er også vanleg i fly.', 'Optisk blanding kan også gjerast ved å projisere grafikk på fysiske gjenstandar. Eksempel: grensesnitta som Berg såg for seg i Dumb things smart light Norviz projeksjon av kart på landskapsmodellar og papirprogrammering frå Dynamicland.', 'Sidan grafikken vert presentert på ei ekstern flate kan fleire personar sjå den samtidig og grafikken endrar seg ikkje når du roterer på hovudet.', 'Nedst til venstre finn vi digital blanding på eksterne flater. Blandinga av den fysiske og virtuelle verda skjer digitalt og resultatet presenterast på ein skjerm.', 'Denne teknikken nyttast ofte på mobiltelefonar og vert då gjerne kalla mobil-AR. Dersom du har spelt Pokémon Go har du kanskje sett korleis kameraet filmar den fysiske verda spelet legg til virtuelle Pokémon-monster og resultatet presenterast på skjermen i realtid.', 'Den vesle mobilskjermen kan kun by på eit bittelite vindu til ei utvida røynd og du må aktivt halde og flytte på mobilen. Dermed er det begrensa kor fantastisk opplevinga av mobil-AR kan verte. Men sidan «alle» har smarttelefonar er det for tida svært mange selskap som investerer tungt i mobil-AR.', 'I øvre høgre hjørne av modellen finn vi dei gjennomsiktige skjermbrillene til dømes Microsoft HoloLens Meta 2 og Mira.', 'Når du har på deg skjermbriller og flyttar på hovudet endrar grafikken seg tilsvarande i brillene. Med andre ord må du ha noko på hovudet og du er (truleg) den einaste som ser den utvida røynda.', 'Ein fordel med denne løysinga er at brukarane kan sjå den fysiske verda rundt seg som dei vanlegvis gjer og har begge hendene frie. Det er derimot ei utfordring at grafikken ikkje alltid er lett å sjå spesielt i skarpt dagslys eller mot ein lys bakgrunn.', 'Til slutt nedst i det høgre hjørnet finn vi skjermbriller med digital blending også kalla «pass-through headsets». Desse brillene liknar på VR-briller men blandar den virtuelle verda med den fysiske verda ved å sende video i realtid frå kamera plassert på brillene.', 'Det er få produkt tilgjengeleg i denne kategorien men rykta seier at Apple arbeider med saka. Denne løysinga kan truleg verte nyttig i mange situasjonar sidan ein unngår utfordringane med optisk blanding som dei gjennomsiktige skjermbrillene slit med.', 'Det sosiale aspektet kan derimot verte ei utfordring med denne løysinga  for korleis er det å samhandle med ein person som har to skjermar rett framfor auga sine?', 'Denne modellen er eit forsøk på å kategorisere AR-landskapet som det ser ut i dag. Landskapet går frå digital til optisk blending frå eksterne flater til skjermbriller.', 'Modellen dekker ikkje lyd som sjølvsagt kan vere ein viktig del av ei utvida røynd. Det hadde vore interessant å utforska om dei same dimensjonane også fungerer for lyd. Eller kanskje lyd fortener sin eigen modell?', 'Frå eit designperspektiv kan modellen kritiserast for å vere for fokusert på teknologi. Må brukarane verkeleg bry seg om korleis blandinga skjer? Nei mest truleg må dei ikkje det. Men som designarar og forskarar må vi forstå materialet vi arbeider med  både avgrensingar og mogelegheiter.', 'I SEDNA-prosjektet som vi arbeider med på Arkitektur- og Designhøgskolen i Oslo er ikkje målet å forske på teknologien i seg sjølv men å finne ut korleis vi kan nytta teknologien for å oppnå situert og distribuert interaksjon. Denne modellen lar oss utforske dei spanande mogelegheitene.', 'Denne teksten var opprinneleg publisert på engelsk i Ocean Industries Concept Lab ei forskingsgruppe ved Arkitektur- og Designhøgskolen i Oslo (AHO).', 'Takk til resten av SEDNA-teamet: Kjetil Nordby Synne Frydenberg og Nicholas Stevens.', 'Originally published at medium.com on August 1 2018.']

title: The most important part of the machine learning is not the machine
subtitle: None
author: Billy Maddocks
h2_headers: ['Working in emerging fields of work often means people are mystified by what I do and how it works. Now the biggest mystery seems to be AI.', '* Know your limitations well or ignore them completely', '* More data doesnt mean a more impressive algorithm', '* The oldest ways are the best…', '* The people part']
paragraphs: ['Throughout my 10 year career as a web developer data analyst manager and consultant among other job titles Ive seen many buzzwords and technologies come and go. Working in emerging fields of work often means people are mystified by what I do and how it works. Just the tiniest self reflection reveals data science/AI meets that criteria in 2018. It seems I like the attention. The difference is I go into it with more experience.', 'Ive learnt some transferable skills - and Id like to share them.', 'Today people design solutions utilising machine learning they dont understand machine learning but they pay lip service by talking about considering its requirements. By considering requirements that you dont understand youre actually limiting a solution in ways you never had to youre designing something that could be better.', 'If you dont understand the considerations its better not to consider them at all design the ideal solution and let the technical experts pull in the limitations. Or do some machine learning code yourself its not that hard honestly.', 'Arent designed screen prototypes basically just the new way of handing over requirements?', 'Designed screens dont actually  in any way  describe any of the AI/machine learning underneath. The best screen designs cover up the AI and technical complexity.', 'Maybe we need a visual way to design algorithms? I tend to think we do.', 'Just because your algorithm has historical data available doesnt mean it makes the right decisions. Machine learning needs to know what data to give what weight to. Not only that it doesnt know what it doesnt know.', 'Unless you tell it otherwise machine algorithms will do the same thing algorithms do not have life experience they have not been conditioned by societal norms. They are as naive and as inexperienced as you let them be.', 'You dont have to look far to find examples of this. The most famous being the racist image recognition algorithm.', 'BBC did a good story on that.', 'Not to mention many times you start to type a search query into google…', 'Some may suggest that this Google search actually shows Google is experienced  Ill leave that to the comments section.', 'Many of the roots of the most common machine learning algorithms are at least 20 years old. Although many of the origins are debatable the table below still illustrates the point that they were conceived before we even knew big data and highly scalable distributed computing was a thing.', 'A highly debatable origin of algorithms table', 'This insight could be taken a number of ways. You could suggest that it means we havent found the best ways to work with big data yet but you could say that this means we have really solid foundations in which to work. This further illustrates my point that there is nothing new at the core with machine learning our technological capabilities around the same core principles may have developed but thats it.', 'The hype is unavoidable around new fun and cool technologies I dont want that to stop I like the enthusiasm and imagination it can bring to people. But the people in the industry who are relied on to consult on such things should not get carried away and should keep grounded in the reality.', 'The future can be at odds with the past when really it should be informing it from the present.', 'I work in a space where I am helping to combine the scientific with the creative the machine with the human the quantitative with the qualitative ontology with phenomenology maths with art.', 'Although my expertise leans towards the machine data and algorithm side I always see that people are the challenge if we get the people part right everything else falls into place. My past experiences seem to point to this too.', 'Peoples perception of what data is and what it can be used for has a large impact on the solutions we can design and build. As Ive also touched on in a previous post about calling data the new oil if we dont understand the nature and power of data or admit what we dont know we cannot make best use of whats in front of us. We as humans must give the AI and machine learning what it needs and tell it what we expect of it with as much clarity as possible. That clarity only comes with understanding and being honest about our own abilities.', 'The most important part of machine learning is not the machine its the people.']

title: Who killed JFK?
subtitle: None
author: Izabela Hawryłko
h2_headers: ['Knowledge Mining can help us solve mysteries of the past and challenges of the future.']
paragraphs: ['100 years. That is how much time we humans needed to double our collective knowledge from 1900. It may seem long but it isnt at all  especially when we take into account that so-called modern humans have existed and gotten smarter and smarter for almost 200 000 years! Then when we move to the year 1945 the climax of the Second World War we might be surprised to learn that at that point in time humankind needed only 25 years to double the aggregated knowledge. This number has recently gone down to 13 months and if predictions of some scientists turn out to be true we will be doubling our collective knowledge every 12th hour as early as 2020. Sounds amazing? Maybe. However this also means that in order to keep using this knowledge in an effective way we will have to be able to store it (or rather the data and information that knowledge is built upon) in an efficient way. For now even the most recent advancements in data center hardware and archiving techniques (like inscribing terabytes of data onto small pieces of quartz glass) dont make us collectively ready for the forthcoming future unless they are operationalised really soon.', 'Cloud technology has at least to some extent helped to tackle the problem of data overload on the level of individual organisations. Companies that understand the importance and value of data have not only digitalised all their documents but have also started to explore the potential of the analysis of data they possess or have access to. Unfortunately there are still many organisations that dont prioritise these efforts and keep terabytes of data related to previous projects profitability resources mistakes and successes mountain-high piles of documents (many of them personal) in physical archives violating basic rules of data security.', 'Just have a look at the picture below. It has quite recently been taken by my colleagues in an anonymous countrys Department of Justice. Hard to believe right? Especially for people working in tech who eat Big Data AI and Machine Learning for breakfast.', 'Its hard to quantify how many valuable insights how many patterns correlations and predictions could be made based on all this data. So what can be done and how to start?', 'This is where the Knowledge Mining process comes into play supported by AI and its cognitive skills. I believe the best way to show how powerful this process is will be to use an example from a specific case in which it was used.', 'In October 2017 Mr. Donald Trump gave his final green light to declassify and make public FBI and CIA records related to the assassination of the former US President John F. Kennedy. 50 000 documents gathered during the past 60 years were uploaded to the National Archives website free for everybody to inspect and as many people hoped learn the truth behind one of the most shocking and scandalous murders in American history. Was Lee Harvey Oswald who was officially charged for the murder a lone wolf or solely an executor of Soviet orders? Unfortunately with no digital tools to search through thousands of PDF files images and records it was impossible to get even the slightest grasp of the case.', 'Not only seasoned researchers got extremely frustrated. Brian and Corom two of my colleagues working in the Cloud & AI division of Microsoft didnt want to accept this situation either. This is also why they kick started a two week sprint as a result of which an easy to use yet powerful solution was created. Brian and Corom called it JFK Files.', 'JFK Files is a simple web application with a search function which allows you to browse thousands of documents and find all relevant information about a given person an institution or a place connected with the JFK case. Something like Bing or Google for specific documents. What is so special about it is that with the help of neural nets and optical character recognition it managed to transform tons of unstructured data both typed (with a typewriter  we are talking about 60 year old documents) and handwritten texts into a searchable format. By using computer vision and celebrity recognition it identified people involved in the murder and captioned their photos. It disclosed cryptonyms. Also it discovered relationships between people organisations and countries and visualised it with knowledge graphs. It distilled old data and information into knowledge. All of this with mostly off-the shelf ready to use algorithms which dont require deep technical expertise to use.', 'So what is Knowledge Mining? If you like definitions Knowledge Mining is a process of data analysis enriched by contextual information and cognitive computing. What is more important is what we can use it for and what value it can bring. How many hours of mundane work on transcribing forms can be saved? How much money can be spared by predicting necessary maintenance of expensive machines? How many fraudulent transactions can we discover and how many can we prevent? How many patients lives can we save by getting insights from all available medical records?', 'There are plenty of cases to look at for inspiration and the sky is the limit.', 'Følg 3min på Facebook så blir du oppdatert på de ferskeste sakene!']

paragraphs: ['We all know that floats are evil. Yet there are moments in life when even something very well known can stab you in the back.', 'We run all our R scripts in Docker. The interface between an R script and our environment is simple: CSV files in designated directories. This means that when a user requests that an R script (e.g. R Transformation) is run on data from table X. Our Docker component will export table X to a CSV file then put that file inside a Docker container and then run the user R script in that container. That R script produces a CSV file Y. Our Docker component then takes this file and creates a table Y from it.', 'During the whole of a dull dark and soundless day in the autumn of the year we received a Zendesk ticket from our customer  lets call him Tim. He was analyzing some table from Google Analytics and then merged it back with another table from Google Analytics. His complaint was that we changed his IDs because the script worked fine when he used it locally in RStudio. This is of course a very serious issue because', 'It turned out that his table was exported from Google Analytics and looked like this:', 'He discovered that the when the script executes (and loads data into our Storage) and attempts to join the data with another table the values of cookieID do not match. Furthermore he discovered that the cookieID values changed slightly e.g. from 7576593838432157975 to 7576593838432157696.', 'When you look at it its crystal clear that its a floating point rounding error. But where? I pointed that out to Tim and he quickly hacked a test to check and prove that the values loaded into his R script were indeed the values returned by his R script. So his script looked like this:', 'So we were a bit stuck until I realized that he missed the very first line in his test. When you load a CSV file into R R is clever enough to guess data types for each of the columns. Unfortunately it is stupid enough to guess data types which cause information loss. So when you load a number like 7576593838432157975. title: Mike Trout’s WAR
subtitle: None
author: M.G. Siegler
h2_headers: ['A ballplayer enters the same breath as Babe Ruth…']
paragraphs: ['In the past 100 years exactly one baseball player has posted a WAR above 14. That was Babe Ruth. That was his best season.¹ That was 95 years ago. Mike Trout is on pace to eclipse that mark this year.', 'Im fascinated by Mike Trout. Hes so clearly the best player in baseball but because hes so understated no one talks about him much. It certainly doesnt help that his team the Los Angeles Angels of Whatever are often mediocre-to-bad.² Some people will try to argue that if he is indeed the best player he should elevate his team to be amongst the best just like LeBron James does with the Cleveland Cavaliers in the NBA. Those people dont understand baseball. One player even the best player even by far the best player can only elevate a team so far.', 'How far? Well theres a stat for that. Its called WAR. In his best seasons Trout has elevated his team to about 10 additional wins. This season he could push them to 14 wins that they likely wouldnt get without him  just like Babe Ruth did for the Yankees in 1923.³', 'Anyway three years ago I wrote about Babe Ruths WAR and how the stat showcased not only just how great he was  but that he was clearly the best ballplayer of all time. Its not just that his 182.5 career WAR is number one on the all-time list  its that hes a full 14.5 WAR ahead of the next closest player: Cy Young.⁴', 'Even better is this list which keeps track of the career leader in WAR every year on an ongoing basis. Cy Young topped the list for nearly 30 straight years until Babe Ruth came along and took over the top spot in 1932. Hes held that same top spot for 86 years and counting.', 'Given everything above hes likely to hold the top spot forever. Except that Trout is about to challenge Ruths best season as Buster Olney laid out last week. Of course it would take sustaining that 10+ WAR level of production over the next decade  yes a crazy thought\u200a to even get close to Ruth. If his production slips or (god forbid) if he gets injured….', 'Anyway the fact that were even having a discussion about that discussion is insane. Because Mike Trout is insane. And its insane that the mainstream doesnt recognize this more fully.', 'Of course the recognition may have to come alongside his next contract. The Angels for all their faults were ingenious with the deal they got Trout to sign in 2014. To some it seemed crazy at the time.⁵ But just a few years later it was obvious to everyone just how good of a deal it was. As The Economist pointed out in late 2016:', 'Mr. Trout is also very very underpaid. To be sure no one will shed a tear for a player who will have made $148m by age 28. But his club the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim (yes for Spanish speakers The The Angels Angels of Anaheim is their full name) wisely inked him to a long-term deal in 2014 at a fraction of his true value. According to Fangraphs his free-market price would likely be more than double the $30m a year he will receive over the next four seasons.', 'Yes $60 million a year. This was followed by a call to do the unthinkable  to trade the best player in baseball:', 'The other is to face the unthinkable and  gasp!  trade Mike Trout. Players with the undisputed title of Best In Baseball™ are rarely dealt and almost never before the final year of their contracts. But the potential return for four years of Mr Trouts peak is hard to contemplate. Were he a free agent today seeking to sign a four-year deal he would probably earn about $250m or $130m more than the Angels will pay him. Based on a recent estimate of the market value of top minor-leaguers  whom MLB teams get to under-pay for up to seven seasons before they become free agents  $130m is roughly equal to the profits a team could expect to extract either from two top-ten MLB-ready youngsters or one budding superstar with five or six years of team control remaining. So lets start the bidding there.', 'The Angels of course didnt do that. But that next contract is going to have to be so large that it will almost ensure Trout will get dragged kicking and screaming into the spotlight.', 'As Michael Baumann noted on that topic for The Ringer last year:', 'Since arriving in the majors Trout has played five full seasons and hes won five Silver Slugger awards and made five All-Star teams. Hes led the American League in WAR five times and finished no worse than second in AL MVP voting including two wins. Since 1901 nobody except Williams has produced more WAR than Trout in his first six seasons though Williams played an extra 81 games and five of those seasons were pre-integration. Trout has the sixth-highest OPS+ (minimum 2500 plate appearances) for a player in his first six years though everyone ahead of him except Ty Cobb was older and played in a less valuable corner position. Trout has two 10-win seasons a feat only five players (Trout Bonds and three Hall of Famers) have ever achieved. At his current pace Trout will close in on 60 career WAR  the modern sabermetric floor for a Hall of Fame career  in early 2018 when hes 26 years old and with less than seven years of service time. Hell have Hall of Fame numbers three years before hes played long enough to be eligible for the Hall of Fame.', 'A year later Trout is slightly behind pace: he will hit 60 WAR sometime in the middle of 2018. He will also crack into the top 10 active players when it comes to WAR (he technically already has with Ichiro Suzuki effectively retiring). All but one other player on the list is over 35 (Zack Greinke turns 35 this season). Again Mike Trout is 26 years old. Its incredible.', 'Anyway just a weekend afternoon baseball statistics aside for everyone. Happy Sunday. ⚾️', '¹ WAR-wise at least.', '² Theyre having a good year this year and are still in third place in their own division…', '³ Yes a year in which they won the World Series like so many Yankees teams in the Ruth-era. And while its not entirely fair (nor entirely accurate) without his 14 WAR the team still would have likely had the best record in the AL that year.', '⁴ Cy Young is just 2.8 points ahead of number three Walter Johnson  who is just 2.4 points ahead of number four the steroid-infused Barry Bonds…', '⁵ Though Ill note that I thought it was smart  talk about understatement.']

title: The Voice
subtitle: None
author: M.G. Siegler
h2_headers: ['Vocal computing has a shot at being the next platform  or more  if the big guys dont screw it up', 'Can You Hear Me Now?', 'Apple: Ahead or Behind?', 'But…', 'Computing in Concert']
paragraphs: ['Over the past few years everyone  investors developers consumers  have been looking for the next platform. 2017 is the ten year anniversary of the iPhone  nine years since it truly became a platform with the launch of the App Store  and it is in no way an overstatement to say that it fundamentally altered the state of computing. In fact its not even an overstatement to say that it altered the state of the entire world in many ways. Smartphones are now undoubtedly the most used device by a huge percentage of the worlds population.', 'So whats next?', 'The hunt has been on basically since the launch of the iPhone. The iPad ushered tablet computing into the mainstream and is a great business but its ultimately an extension of the smartphone and morphing with the laptop. Google Glass was clearly a slightly off approach at the wrong time. Apple Watch is a nice-to-have but not vital to anyones day-to-day. Maybe that changes down the road  in particular if the tracking of vitals becomes the key to the device  but its not there right now. The same feels true with AR/VR; getting more interesting by the day but still a bit too early.', 'And so we wait.', 'But what if the next interesting platform has been under our noses the whole time? Or rather right around our noses. Our mouths and ears…', 'Ive been intrigued by the power of voice with regard to computing for a long time. Back in the 1990s I bought one of those awful Microsoft dictation microphones for Windows. It was laughably bad. Microsoft Bob bad. So bad I cant even seem to find it anywhere on the internet anymore to link to it! It has been erased from history. That bad.', 'Later I also owned one of the first Bluetooth headsets. Yes I was that guy. That cyborg guy. More recently Ive hacked my iPhone to basically read everything to me (via a more subtle Bluetooth headset).', 'I consider voice to be both talking and listening  vocal and audible computing. Sometimes use cases call for one aspect sometimes the other. Sometimes both. But theyre clearly tied together in my mind. To that end I think a confluence of events has made it possible that this will be the next truly interesting platform. Again for investors developers and consumers.', 'Everyone knows about Amazons Alexa by now. Well by everyone I mean everyone who is likely to read this post. In reality Amazon has still only sold five million or so Echos so far. Apple has sold a billion iPhones. Perspective matters.', 'But thats okay because the Echo was simply the first vessel in which Alexa entered our lives. Amazon is now pushing Alexa far beyond that first device. Thats easier said than done of course. But if this years CES is any indication this is happening.', 'Directionally the same seems to be true with Googles Assistant. Google Home is just one outlet for the service. Notably billions of Android devices are potential conduits. Cortana + Microsoft. Etc.', 'And then theres Siri. While Apple had the foresight to acquire Siri and make it a marquee feature of the iPhone  in 2011!  before their competitors knew what was happening Apple has treated Siri like well an Apple product. That is iterate secretly behind the scenes and focus on new big functionality only when they deem it ready to ship usually timed with a new version of iOS. Thats great but Im not sure its the right way forward for this new computing paradigm  things are changing far too quickly.', 'This is where I insert buzzwords. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning. AI. Machine Learning…', 'But really: AI. Machine Learning.', 'I found a recent interview Apple SVP of Marketing Phil Schiller did with Steven Levy rather illuminating on Apples thinking. One key part:', 'Two dismissals in there worry me about Apples approach.', 'First that they believe the phone is far more interesting than having a stand-alone product in the space right now. I maybe  maybe¹  agree with the general sentiment in the long term. But in the short term its folly to dismiss the importance of having a dedicated device. For a thousand reasons.', 'With the technical hurdles to vocal computing quickly fading away the key is normalizing it. Weve been able to talk to our phones for years but its still awkward to do this most of the time. I dont know about you but when I do it I still pretend like Im talking on the phone. To another human being. Like an animal.', 'Second with regard to the screen… The brilliance of the Echo is that the only way to interact with it is through voice. This is a forcing function. While it may be easier to do some things via a screen or keyboard in many cases thats in large part because functionality to make such action more robust was built out over time. Further continuing to use such functions will simply perpetuate those paradigms.', 'I agree that for many things those inputs are the better way to do things right now  and presumably this is why Amazon is working on an Echo with a screen  but to enable the future of functionality we need to break habits. The Echo showcases this perfectly.', 'Anyway I suspect Schiller is being a bit disingenuous here. Rumors have Apple working on its own Echo-like device so this could simply be an old Steve Jobs-like maneuver of dismissing a space until you launch a competitor. But if Apple truly believes that the phone is going to be the real gateway here they risk ceding the era to Amazon who is thinking about it the exact opposite way  Alexa not just on a phone but everywhere.² An operating system for all things connected.³', 'This leads to the AirPods. With each passing day I love these things even more. And while theyre sort of symbolically tied to music right now (thanks to the similar look to Apples iconic white EarPods which became synonymous with iTunes via all those brilliant ads) they are perhaps the perfect product yet for the vocal computing world laid out above.', 'Theyre not just good for music theyre great for audiobooks for podcasts for listening to anything via my voiceover hack. And of course they include a microphone for the other part of the equation. Yes EarPods were good for all of this too  the difference as Im coming to realize is that you can almost leave the AirPods in all day without even realizing theyre there. Theyre an extension of your body  one thats always connected to the internet via your iPhone (or iPad or Mac).⁴', 'More importantly the fact that Apple built-in the ability to trigger Siri (double-tap) almost negates my concerns about Apple in this space as mentioned above. If it were well done  meaning worked more than a fraction of the time on first attempt  it might fully negate my concerns.', 'Of course such functionality needs to be more fleshed out presumably through Siri (though not necessarily) to let a thousand apps and services flourish. And not just the obvious ones like podcasts etc. For this world to really take off were going to need a thousand new types of services.', 'Think about services that may be voice-first. Its really hard to do that right now in our current world. But theres clearly opportunity there. What if this is not just the next platform but the future of computing in general…', 'Again Amazon has the lead here. A couple nights ago my wife and I started playing Jeopardy with Alexa. It was brilliant. So seamless so obvious so much less overhead than launching a visual-based game (whether on the phone or on a video game console) so much more interactive than watching television (where Alex Trebek wont tell us specifically how we did).', 'Its a silly example. But some of the biggest things start as silly examples. Youve undoubtedly heard this ad nauseum but worth repeating until you get it: watch a child talk to Alexa. Thats also silly  until all those children grow up and start to interact with all of their computers this way.', '¹ This is the vision of the future that everyone points to in the movie Her of course. But in that world Theodore doesnt interact with Samantha mainly on a smartphone but rather through an earpiece. The screen is the backup device for certain visual tasks…', '² Of course thats a lot easier to do when you tried to launch a phone and utterly failed.', '³ Wouldnt it be interesting if after all the wasted words about the operating system for the home it wasnt one of the living room devices like Apple TV or Xbox but rather Amazon that nailed this via Alexa?', '⁴ Yeah battery life has to be better than 5 hours to make this a true reality but as long as youre not constantly listening to music the effective battery life is much longer.', 'More thoughts:']

title: Week 13: Aksh Gupta, Occasion

author: Crissy Costa
paragraphs: ['Speaking with Aksh Gupta its clear that he knows SMBs. While customer empathy is something most founders claim to have Akshs ability to truly knows his customers sets him apart. Coming from a long line of small-scale entrepreneurs Askh understands the pains of small business owners. Thats why Aksh started Occasion a booking platform designed to scale customer acquisition across all channels and devices while providing a seamless brand experience. Occasion even handles marketing for its customers going beyond the traditional reservation management platform. The company knows how critical empathy is when building products and now offers its employees an apprenticeship program to work alongside SMBs in order to translate customer pains into new features. This unique approach will continue to serve the company well especially at the helm of such an insightful entrepreneur.', 'Stage 👉 SeedLocation 👉 ChicagoIndustry 👉 Booking Software', 'There are always things outside of your control but if you have even a single regret that you did not give it all thats whats heartbreaking. title: Week 14: Aleksandra Woźniak, Cleo
subtitle: None
author: Crissy Costa
paragraphs: ['This week kicks off my three part London founder series with Aleksandra Woźniak Cofounder and CTO of Cleo your personal financial assistant. Cleo began in early 2016 at Entrepreneur First Europes leading accelerator for technical talent and now helps its users manager over £120M. Thinking back on my time in London its fitting that this series begins with my first female CTO interview. While I only was fortunate enough to meet with a few founders during my time in London a clear differentiator was the breadth of diversity I saw in both in tech and the population at large.
